article.body: In 1967, Warren Buffett told investors that he was âout of step with present conditions,â an admission that he couldnât wrap his head around the market climate at the time. âI will not abandon a previous approach whose logic I understand (although I find it difficult to apply),â Buffett explained, âeven though it may mean foregoing large, and apparently easy, profits to embrace an approach which I donât fully understand, have not practiced successfully, and which possibly could lead to substantial permanent loss of capital.â Kailish Concepts, a quant analysis firm, used those very words from the Berkshire Hathaway BRK.B, +0.24% Â boss in a note taking a deep dive into the âdeath of valuationâ in todayâs market, which can be seen by this telling chart showing the dominance of growth stocks: âKailash believes the idea that things are different this time to be a very old and very flawed story,â the analysts wrote, adding that they believe that âmuch of Nasdaqâs manic run is simply a wall of money chasing what was already racing higher.â Joining the likes of high-profile Wall Street names like Jeremy Grantham, David Tepper, Stanley Druckenmiller, Cliff Asness and Howard Marks, to name a few, Kailish explained that, as the chart suggests, the stock market is clearly in bubble territory. And weâve seen this play out before. âThe most expensive firms in the market today, like in August of 2000, generate no FCF, are loss-making and carry the associated negative ROEs and ROAs, and are diluting shareholders to fund operations,â Kailish wrote. âWith spreads between value and growth at record levels and an explosion of speculative listings through IPOs and SPACs underway, todayâs market environment shares numerous features with prior peaks in 2000 and 2007.â No sign of a popping bubble as stocks got a bit more expensive to start the week and held gains on Tuesday. At last check, the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +0.56% Â , Nasdaq Composite COMP, +1.39% and S&P 500 SPX, +0.87% were all hovering around breakeven.
